comments.body: probably not worth doing a re-push for this, but I (personally) like having syntax highlighting for supported languages in documentation, so in the future could you toss a ```<lang> at the top (in this case ```yaml)?

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +9,13 @@output every second [counter-pod.yaml](/examples/blog-logging/counter-pod.yaml):
```
 apiVersion: v1
 kind: Pod
 metadata:

comments.body:
Dont we need the trailing slash?

@satnam6502

This is a direct copy of the output of `kubectl cluster-info`. 

I think we need the trailing slash if we want to `curl` the proxy.
Yes, for Elasticsearch we need the trailing slash so access from curl and other CLI tools.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +18,22 @@into Elasticsearch.
```
Elasticsearch is running at https://104.197.10.10/api/v1beta3/proxy/namespaces/default/services/elasticsearch-logging
Kibana is running at https://104.197.10.10/api/v1beta3/proxy/namespaces/default/services/kibana-logging
```

comments.body: Presumably this is a password specific to your cluster.
Yes, there is a comment after this block that asks the read to get the password from the auth file generated during cluster creation time. Does this needed to be clearer?
I think it'd be slightly clearer if you moved that comment up above the wall of text. Your call.
Thanks to both of you for this good suggestion. Done.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +28,32 @@You can check to see if any logs are being ingested into Elasticsearch by curling against its URL. You will need to provide the username and password that was generated when your cluster was created. This can be found in the `kubernetes_auth` file for your cluster.
```
curl -k -u admin:Drt3KdRGnoQL6TQM https://130.211.152.93/api/v1beta1/proxy/services/elasticsearch-logging/_search?size=10
